response.answer_text: Yes. As an ethnicity, they are collectively called Copts, though, fun fact, not all of them are part of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria (the largest and most-ancient Christian denomination in the area). When my dad (an ELCA pastor) was in seminary, we lived in an apartment just upstairs from an Egyptian family, one of his classmates Magdi and his wife Heba. Their oldest kid, by the name of Wasim, was the same age as me, and we were good friends until their family went back. They taught us how to make baklava, which is delicious. The pickled beets, I did not like quite so well. I can still remember our families watching a production of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat on TV together down in their apartment. Just throwing that out there.
Yup. They are Coptic Christians or Copts. Some 10 million of them are in Egypt and they are probably one of the oldest Christian communities as well.
